ERROR: invocation failed (errno 2), args: ['/usr/local/google/home/valentyn/projects/beam/py_sdk_default_runner_harness_container/beam/sdks/python/target/.tox/lint/bin/pip', 'install', 'nose==1.3.7', 'pycodestyle==2.3.1', 'pylint==1.7.1'], cwd: /usr/local/google/home/valentyn/projects/beam/py_sdk_default_runner_harness_container/beam/sdks/python

R: @herohde @kennknowles

Cham has advised me to find a reviewer that is more familiar with side inputs. 
r: @charlesccychen could you take a look?

A quick summary of the change:
In the Insights team we're working on a project to keep track of time spent / bytes read from side inputs, so that users may be better informed of bottlenecks in their pipelines.
For this, we track msecs spent *blocked* waiting for side inputs (so, only when the Queue is empty ahead of time).

An interesting, and perhaps counter-intuitive scenario that we're planning for is the following dummy example:

```
si_iterable = AsIter(p | Create(long_list))

def emit_side_input(e, si_iter):
  yield si_iter

pcoll = p 
  | Create([0]) 
  | 'step1' >> beam.Map(emit_side_input, si_iter=si_iterable) 
  | 'step2' >> beam.FlatMap(lambda x: list(x))
```

In this case, `step1` emits the iterable, and `step2` is the one that actually may be blocked waiting for side inputs. That's why we need to check the current step when the thread blocks.

I'd like a review of the approach, and I'll come back with benchmark results soon. Hope it's not much trouble, Charles. Thanks.
Best
-P.

Hopefully this resolves things; will be keeping an eye on the tests. 

Could you at least reference the original commit (if not creating as a rollback) and give a reason in the commit description?

Python failure looks like [BEAM-3040](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-3040) while Java failure is a WordCountIT job that actually succeeded (I checked directly) but terminated in state UNKNOWN.
run Java PreCommit
Wait, false. It actually timed out after 10 minutes so that is perhaps a real failure. This PR should not affect it so I'll check.
Thank you @robertwb. I wanted to just run the pre-commit with the change to see if it helps. I will update the commit message with relevant information.
Not a real failure in Beam - the worker pool was stopped after 3 minutes, because the job completed successfully. The client timed out 7 minutes after the job was actually done.

cc: @herohde @jasonkuster 

I think the test failures in the release branch are related to https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/3965. If I understand correctly Jenkins execute tests based on the groovy files from the master. This PR updated one of those files with a project reference to `sdks/python/container`. However that project was only added to the master branch and not to the release branch. That is why precommit tests in release branch are failing.

We can either rollback the groovy change, or if it is safe CP the original change to the release branch.

CC: @kennknowles 

We should really not use test scripts from master in release branches. The groovy change would break master, if rolled back. CPing the Python container PR is probably safe assuming the changes it depends on are present, but sets a poor precedent.

Alternatively, given that the container is last in the test, perhaps just ignore the failure?

R: @kennknowles 
CC: @wcn3

I agree that the testing setup needs to change.

The alternative (ignoring the results) is not viable because tests fails early on without executing anything else. The error is "Could not find the selected project in the reactor: sdks/python/container". Someone with maven knowledge can comment on why that is happening.

> CPing the Python container PR is probably safe assuming the changes it depends on are present

What are the the things that it depends? Since the release branch is cut recently, I guess that will be the case.
R: @ananvay
LGTM, thanks Ahmet!
Pick any package names you like - it should be as idiomatic as possible. I am not particularly attached even to the Java names.
BTW I knew this needed doing but decided to leave it for a minute since there were enough conflicts and revisions needed on the first PR.
We should figure a way to either automate the headers or exclude them from the RAT check. I'll check the policy and also tooling.
R: @kennknowles @lukecwik

I agree _strongly_ that the test scripts should live alongside the code.

The test scripts reference aspects of the repo which change, such as which modules are present. That is what is going wrong now. We have previously had issues with the scripts referencing maven profiles and whatnot which either do or do not exist when needed. It has only gotten worse, and I expect the trend to continue, since the flaw is conceptual.

When we moved from Travis to Jenkins I wanted to keep this property of tests evolving with code, which Travis-CI has naturally, by having a script in the repo that Jenkins would invoke. This also minimizes Jenkins churn, which is quite tedious to debug and very hard to test in advance.

There were some specious objections about execution of arbitrary code, which you can always do and is sort of the point. Beyond that, the tight integration with Jenkins plugins may not be possible. The current issue is strong evidence that technical necessity outweighs those niceties.

It is some real work, but if the hacks below don't immediately solve things, it may be simplest to move in the right direction here and alter the Jenkins jobs to just invoke a script so it can be different on `master` and this branch.

> The error is "Could not find the selected project in the reactor: sdks/python/container". Someone with maven knowledge can comment on why that is happening.

This is happening because `sdks/python/container` does not exist, just as the discussion has mentioned. The Python precommit specifies `--projects 'sdks/python,!sdks/python/container'` to avoid building the container. It is unfortunate that this is a fatal error.

Possibilities:

 - One hack to avoid this would be to control this with a profile, which is not a fatal error if missing. The new toggle would be  `--activate-profiles '!python-container'`. That is not a good long-term solution because poms are gross enough with hacks kept to a minimum.
 - We could also remove the `--also-make-dependents` since I think the Python SDKs model of including all code in a single module makes it irrelevant. My experience trying to run build all submodules, as with `--projects runners` is that it does _not_ build submodules by default, so you can build `--projects sdks/python` and it will not automatically build the submodule.

Nice. I like that now that we have two non-harness entities that nonetheless go by the name "harness" we can start to build support libraries for "harnesses". I look forward to a meta-harness injection harness framework harness.
Look at #3941?
